channel.title: The Complete List of Data Management Terms And Their Definitions on Tech Terminologies
channel.description: Recent content in The Complete List of Data Management Terms And Their Definitions on Tech Terminologies

item.title: What is Run-length Encoding?
item.description: Run-length encoding is a simple method of compressing data by identifying and replacing repeated sequences of identical data with a single instance of that data, along with a count of how many times it appears in the original file.

item.title: What is an Orphan File?
item.description: An orphan file, also known as a “stray file,” is a type of computer file that has been separated from its associated data or metadata.

item.title: What is a Compressed File?
item.description: A compressed file is a type of data file that has had its size reduced through a process known as data compression.

item.title: What is the Binary Format?
item.description: The binary format is a method of encoding data in a computer system using only two values, typically represented as 0 and 1.

item.title: What is a Binary File?
item.description: A binary file is a type of computer file that contains data in a binary format, which is a series of bits that represent machine-readable instructions and data.

item.title: What is a File (Computer File)?
item.description: A file, in the context of a computer, is a collection of data that is stored on a computer’s hard drive, an external hard drive, or some other form of storage.

item.title: What is a File Extension?
item.description: A file extension is a set of characters that is added to the end of a file name and helps to identify the type of file.

item.title: What is Cloud Security Control?
item.description: Cloud security controls refer to the measures that organizations put in place to ensure the security and integrity of their data and systems when using cloud computing services.

item.title: What is Data in Use?
item.description: Data in use refers to data that is actively being accessed and processed by a computer or device for a specific purpose.

item.title: What is SATA (Serial ATA)?
item.description: Serial ATA (SATA) is a computer bus interface that connects host bus adapters to mass storage devices such as hard drives and optical drives.

item.title: What is Ultra DMA (Ultra Direct Memory Access)?
item.description: Ultra DMA (Ultra Direct Memory Access) is a data transfer technology used in computers to improve the speed of data transfer between the computer’s hard disk drive and the system memory.

item.title: What is Torrent?
item.description: Torrent is a file-sharing technology that allows users to download and share large files, for example, movies, music, and software, over the internet.

item.title: What is XMP (Extensible Metadata Platform)?
item.description: XMP (Extensible Metadata Platform) is a standard for storing and organizing metadata (data about data) in a digital file.

item.title: What is EXIF (Exchangeable Image File Format)?
item.description: EXIF, or Exchangeable Image File Format, is a type of metadata that is embedded in a digital image file.

item.title: What is CDFS (Compact Disc File System)?
item.description: The Compact Disc File System, also known as CDFS, is a file system used to store and access data on a compact disc.

item.title: What is a Swap File?
item.description: A swap file, also known as a swap space or a paging file, is a space on a hard drive or other storage device that is used to store data temporarily when the system’s main memory (RAM) becomes full.

item.title: What is PostScript?
item.description: PostScript is a programming language and page description language used mainly in the printing and desktop publishing industries.

item.title: What is Document Grinding?
item.description: Document grinding, also known as document shredding or document destruction, is the process of securely destroying physical documents to protect sensitive information from being accessed by unauthorized parties.

item.title: What is Compression (Data Compression)?
item.description: Data compression is a technique used to represent data in a more compact form in order to reduce the amount of storage space required or to transmit the data more efficiently over a network.

item.title: What is Metadata?
item.description: The term “metadata” refers to any data that contains information about other types of data.

item.title: What is DRM (Digital Rights Management)?
item.description: Digital rights management (DRM) is a technology used to protect digital content and prevent unauthorized access, copying, or distribution.

item.title: What is a Raw File Format (Raw Image Format)?
item.description: A raw image format is a file format that stores unprocessed data from a digital camera’s image sensor.

item.title: What is a Permalink?
item.description: A permalink, short for “permanent link,” is a URL (Uniform Resource Locator) that is intended to remain unchanged for the lifetime of the content to which it refers.

item.title: What is NoSQL Database?
item.description: NoSQL, also known as “Not Only SQL,” is a type of database that is designed to handle large volumes of structured, semi-structured, or unstructured data.

item.title: What is a Datagram?
item.description: A “datagram” is a self-contained, independent entity of data carrying sufficient information to be routed from the source to the destination computer without reliance on earlier exchanges between the source and destination computers and the transporting network.

item.title: What is the 404 Error (Not Found)?
item.description: The 404 error is an HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) status code that indicates that the server was unable to find the requested resource.

item.title: What is the 403 Error (Forbidden)?
item.description: A 403 error is an HTTP status code that indicates that a client is forbidden from accessing a requested resource.

item.title: What is CDN (Content Delivery Network)?
item.description: A Content Delivery Network (CDN) is a globally distributed network of servers that work together to deliver content to users as efficiently as possible.

item.title: What is ICT (Information and Communications Technology)?
item.description: Information and communications technology, or ICT, refers to the various technologies and tools used to facilitate the exchange of information and communication.

item.title: What is Parity Check?
item.description: “Parity check” is a method of checking the accuracy of data transmission or storage.

item.title: What is a Master Reset?
item.description: A master reset, also known as a factory reset or hard reset, is the process of resetting a device to its original factory settings, effectively wiping all data, and returning it to the state it was in when it was initially acquired.

item.title: What is a Hard Reset?
item.description: A hard reset, also known as a factory reset or master reset, is the process of restoring a device to its original manufacturer settings.

item.title: What is a Factory Reset?
item.description: A factory reset, also known as a hard reset or master reset, is the process of restoring a device to its original manufacturer settings.

item.title: What is Encoding?
item.description: Encoding is the process of converting data from one format into another for the purpose of efficient transmission or storage.

item.title: What is ACL (Access Control List)?
item.description: An access control list (ACL) is a list of permissions that are associated with a particular resource, such as a file, folder, or network device.

item.title: What is Access (Microsoft Access)?
item.description: Microsoft Access is a database management system (DBMS) that is part of the Microsoft Office suite of productivity software.

item.title: What is a Memory Address?
item.description: A memory address is a unique identifier for a specific location in a computer’s memory.

item.title: What is Cloud Waste?
item.description: Cloud waste refers to the inefficient use of resources, such as computing power and storage, in cloud computing environments.
